etymology.description: 小 + 龙 = small + dragon → ‘little dragon’ used euphemistically for the Snake zodiac.
etymology.interpretation: A polite, auspicious nickname for the Snake sign in the Chinese zodiac, replacing “蛇” with the more favorable “龙”. Emphasizes positivity or avoids taboo associations with snakes.
etymology.simplification: 小 is unchanged; 龍 was simplified to 龙 in Mainland reforms to reduce strokes and standardize forms.

examples.english: My zodiac sign is the snake (literally ‘little dragon’).

examples.chinese: 老人家忌讳说蛇(老人家忌諱說蛇)，喜欢说小龙(喜歡說小龍)。
examples.pinyin: Lǎorénjiā jìhuì shuō shé, xǐhuan shuō xiǎolóng.
examples.english: Elders avoid saying “snake” and prefer to say “little dragon.”

examples.chinese: 民间把蛇叫小龙(民間把蛇叫小龍)，图个吉利(圖個吉利)。
examples.pinyin: Mínjiān bǎ shé jiào xiǎolóng, tú gè jílì.
examples.english: Among the folk, people call snakes “little dragons” for good luck.
